Hardening an Ubuntu server is a key step to protect any infrastructure exposed to the internet. Below are essential actions you can take to significantly improve security, with a summary table of each configuration’s effects.
üîê Step 1: Create a secure user and use SSH keys Disable direct root access and use a limited user with SSH keys to enhance traceability and eliminate a common attack vector.
adduser secureuser usermod -aG sudo secureuser Then copy your public key to the server:
ssh-copy-id secureuser@your-server üîê Step 2: Disable SSH access for root Edit /etc/ssh/sshd_config:
PermitRootLogin no üîê Step 3: Disable password authentication To enforce key-based login only:
PasswordAuthentication no Restart SSH:
sudo systemctl restart ssh üîÅ Step 4: Enable automatic security updates Install and configure:
sudo apt install unattended-upgrades sudo dpkg-reconfigure --priority=low unattended-upgrades This ensures timely patching without manual intervention.
üì¶ Step 5: Install fail2ban Fail2ban automatically blocks brute-force login attempts:
sudo apt install fail2ban sudo systemctl enable --now fail2ban Basic jail for SSH:
# /etc/fail2ban/jail.local [sshd] enabled = true üîÑ Step 6: Configure reverse ProxyJump (bastion) From your local machine (e.g., a Mac), set up ~/.ssh/config:
Host private-node HostName 10.0.0.3 User secureuser ProxyJump bastion Host bastion HostName 123.456.789.000 User secureuser üìä Step 7: Monitor with Uptime Kuma Uptime Kuma is a sleek status monitoring tool with a web dashboard:
docker run -d --restart=always -p 3001:3001 \ -v uptime-kuma:/app/data --name uptime kuma uptimekuma/uptime-kuma Access it at http://your-ip:3001.
üìú Step 8: Script to rotate SSH keys Create a script at /usr/local/bin/rotate_ssh.sh:
#!/bin/bash USER="secureuser" KEY_DIR="/home/$USER/.ssh" NEW_KEY="$KEY_DIR/id_ed25519_new" ssh-keygen -t ed25519 -f "$NEW_KEY" -N "" cat "$NEW_KEY.pub" >> "$KEY_DIR/authorized_keys" echo "New key added. Manually remove the old one after verifying access." üîê Step 9: Enable 2FA with Google Authenticator sudo apt install libpam-google-authenticator google-authenticator Then edit /etc/pam.d/sshd and add at the top:
auth required pam_google_authenticator.so And in /etc/ssh/sshd_config:
ChallengeResponseAuthentication yes Restart SSH:
sudo systemctl restart ssh Summary Step Effect secureuser + SSH keys Replaces direct root access PermitRootLogin no Blocks root login brute force attempts PasswordAuthentication no Enforces key-only login UFW Restricts open ports SSH timeout & retry limits Prevents slow brute-force attempts Fail2ban Auto-bans after failed logins ProxyJump Enables safe SSH from bastion Unattended upgrades Keeps system patched Uptime Kuma Visual monitoring SSH key rotation Enhances access hygiene Google Authenticator Adds two-factor authentication With these steps, you‚Äôll have a solid foundation for a secure and maintainable server. For even stronger security, consider audit tools like Lynis, internal port scans, and network segmentation.

Disable direct root access and use a limited user with SSH keys to enhance traceability and eliminate a common attack vector.

adduser secureuser
usermod -aG sudo secureuser

Then copy your public key to the server:

Useful RPC Commands for a Nano Node Once your Nano node is running and port 7076 is open, you can interact with it using HTTP POST requests to the JSON-RPC API. Below is a collection of useful commands organized by category.
üîç Node Status curl -d '{ "action": "version" }' -H "Content-Type: application/json" http://127.0.0.1:7076 curl -d '{ "action": "telemetry" }' -H "Content-Type: application/json" http://127.0.0.1:7076 curl -d '{ "action": "block_count" }' -H "Content-Type: application/json" http://127.0.0.1:7076 üß≠ Network & Peers curl -d '{ "action": "peers" }' -H "Content-Type: application/json" http://127.0.0.1:7076 curl -d '{ "action": "peer_add", "address": "peering.nano.org", "port": "7075" }' \ -H "Content-Type: application/json" http://127.0.0.1:7076 üîê Wallets & Accounts curl -d '{ "action": "wallet_list" }' -H "Content-Type: application/json" http://127.0.0.1:7076 curl -d '{ "action": "wallet_create" }' -H "Content-Type: application/json" http://127.0.0.1:7076 curl -d '{ "action": "account_create", "wallet": "<WALLET_ID>" }' \ -H "Content-Type: application/json" http://127.0.0.1:7076 curl -d '{ "action": "wallet_add", "wallet": "<WALLET_ID>", "key": "<PRIVATE_KEY>" }' \ -H "Content-Type: application/json" http://127.0.0.1:7076 üí¨ Account Information curl -d '{ "action": "account_balance", "account": "<ACCOUNT_ID>" }' \ -H "Content-Type: application/json" http://127.0.0.1:7076 curl -d '{ "action": "account_info", "account": "<ACCOUNT_ID>" }' \ -H "Content-Type: application/json" http://127.0.0.1:7076 üõ† Administration curl -d '{ "action": "representatives_online" }' \ -H "Content-Type: application/json" http://127.0.0.1:7076 curl -d '{ "action": "bootstrap_any" }' \ -H "Content-Type: application/json" http://127.0.0.1:7076 üóÇ References Official Nano RPC Documentation NanoLooker Explorer Nano Node Directory ‚ö†Ô∏è Disclaimer This guide is intended to document practical JSON-RPC commands for interacting with a self-hosted Nano node. While its contents have been carefully reviewed, it may not function identically across all environments or configurations.
Use at your own risk. Always make backups before altering configurations or handling private keys.
For support or questions, refer to the Nano documentation or the Nano community forums.

Useful RPC Commands for a Nano Node

Once your Nano node is running and port 7076 is open, you can interact with it using HTTP POST requests to the JSON-RPC API. Below is a collection of useful commands organized by category.

üîç Node Status

curl -d '{ "action": "version" }' -H "Content-Type: application/json" http://127.0.0.1:7076

curl -d '{ "action": "telemetry" }' -H "Content-Type: application/json" http://127.0.0.1:7076

curl -d '{ "action": "block_count" }' -H "Content-Type: application/json" http://127.0.0.1:7076

üß≠ Network & Peers

curl -d '{ "action": "peers" }' -H "Content-Type: application/json" http://127.0.0.1:7076

curl -d '{ "action": "peer_add", "address": "peering.nano.org", "port": "7075" }' \
     -H "Content-Type: application/json" http://127.0.0.1:7076

üîê Wallets & Accounts

curl -d '{ "action": "wallet_list" }' -H "Content-Type: application/json" http://127.0.0.1:7076

curl -d '{ "action": "wallet_create" }' -H "Content-Type: application/json" http://127.0.0.1:7076

curl -d '{ "action": "account_create", "wallet": "<WALLET_ID>" }' \
     -H "Content-Type: application/json" http://127.0.0.1:7076

curl -d '{ "action": "wallet_add", "wallet": "<WALLET_ID>", "key": "<PRIVATE_KEY>" }' \
     -H "Content-Type: application/json" http://127.0.0.1:7076

üí¨ Account Information

curl -d '{ "action": "account_balance", "account": "<ACCOUNT_ID>" }' \
     -H "Content-Type: application/json" http://127.0.0.1:7076

curl -d '{ "action": "account_info", "account": "<ACCOUNT_ID>" }' \
     -H "Content-Type: application/json" http://127.0.0.1:7076

üõ† Administration

curl -d '{ "action": "representatives_online" }' \
     -H "Content-Type: application/json" http://127.0.0.1:7076

curl -d '{ "action": "bootstrap_any" }' \
     -H "Content-Type: application/json" http://127.0.0.1:7076

üóÇ References

  • Official Nano RPC Documentation
  • NanoLooker Explorer
  • Nano Node Directory

‚ö†Ô∏è Disclaimer

This guide is intended to document practical JSON-RPC commands for interacting with a self-hosted Nano node. While its contents have been carefully reviewed, it may not function identically across all environments or configurations.
